conclusion: Diffraction is the bending of light waves around the edges of an obstacle or through a narrow opening.
The likelihood of diffraction increases with the wavelength of the light.
Two monochromatic light beams, a and b, with different frequencies are incident perpendicularly onto the flat surface AB of a hemispherical glass brick.
Both beams are equidistant from point C, the midpoint of AB.
After refraction, both beams intersect at point P inside the glass brick.
Frequency and wavelength are inversely related: higher frequency light has a shorter wavelength.
Both beams refract at the flat surface AB and intersect at point P.
Since light b is more likely to exhibit diffraction than light a, light b must have a longer wavelength than light a.
Light b has a lower frequency than light a.
Light b, with a longer wavelength, is more likely to exhibit diffraction than light a.
